subject: Ethics
title: Augustine's Just War Origins
description: A micro-lesson that makes Augustine's Just War Origins usable.

hook.text: In 400 AD, a bishop asked: can a Christian ever kill in war? His answer shaped 1,600 years of ethics.

buildup.text: Augustine argued that war is sinfulâ€”but sometimes necessary to stop a greater evil like tyranny.

discovery.text: He created the first 'just war' framework: war needs a just cause, right intention, and proper authority.

twist.text: Augustine never said war was good. He said soldiers who kill justly should still weep for what they've done.

climax.text: His framework became the foundation for international law, military ethics, and the Geneva Conventions.

punchline.text: A bishop's guilt became the world's rules for war.

quiz.question: What was unique about Augustine's view on just war?
options: He believed war could be necessary but soldiers should still grieve the killing
He said war was always morally good if authorized by the Church
He argued that only defensive wars could ever be justified
